p: IPCC defines Southern Africa as a region likely to experience an increase in temperature that exceeds the global average [ 1]. In South Africa the average annual temperatures are reported to have increased by 1.5 °C times the observed 0.65 °C over the past five decades [ 8]. The frequency in extreme rainfalls has also increased [ 8]. It is predicted that interior regions of South Africa will warm by a further ~ 3–4 °C by 2100 [ 8].
